node.title: The rare frog that swallows its babies is now extinct —  but could cloning bring it back?
node.alt: A man crouched over looks into a clear creek, surrounded by greenery and rainforest.
node.description: The Eungella gastric-brooding frog is now believed extinct —  but in a real-life Jurassic Park scenario, some scientists are working to undo that.
node.content:
["It's the bizarre frog of legend that swallows their own fertilised eggs, incubating them in its stomach before spitting out baby frogs once they have grown.\u00a0", "But a last-ditch effort by scientists to find\u00a0the Eungella gastric-brooding frog in remote rainforests of north Queensland have proved unsuccessful, all but confirming the critically endangered species is extinct.\u00a0", "Dr Conrad Hoskin, a tropical biologist from James Cook University, was one of several scientists who travelled by helicopter\u00a0into the western side of the Eungella range, spending three\u00a0nights camping and surveying the creeks for signs of frogs.\u00a0", "He had hoped that the isolated location, along with the warmer conditions might prove to be a\u00a0refuge for endangered frogs to survive and live with the devastating chytrid fungus.", "", "
While their search for the gastric-brooding frog was unsuccessful, the scientists did find populations of rare frogs, like this Eungella day frog.\u00a0(Supplied: Conrad Hoskin)
", "\"We often find a species we thought was extinct\u00a0in these areas where the disease is present, but doesn't impact the frog population as dramatically,\" Dr Hoskin said.", "As a final confirmation, water samples have been taken from the sites to be checked for any residual DNA from the frogs upstream.\u00a0", "
From critical to extinct
", "The Eungella, or northern gastric-brooding frog, was the larger relative of the southern species, last seen in the wild in the late 1970s or early 1980s.\u00a0", "While the southern species has been believed to be extinct since the 1980s, some scientists had held onto hope the northern species was still living and hiding in the cold streams of\u00a0largely inaccessible country.\u00a0", "\"It [the northern gastric-brooding frog]\u00a0sits at critically endangered, and that's on the cusp of going extinct now,\" Dr Hoskin\u00a0said.\u00a0", "But while Dr Hoskin believes this was the final search he will undertake\u00a0for the elusive amphibian,\u00a0he was excited to also find populations of other critically endangered frogs on his trip.\u00a0", "", "
The final surveys for the gastric-brooding frog meant several days for scientists in waist deep water, recording the animals they found.\u00a0(Supplied: Conrad Hoskin)
", "The Eungella day frog, Eungella tinker frog and the tusked frog were all identified by Dr Hoskin on the trip, two of which are endemic to the region and found nowhere else in the world.\u00a0", "\"It's obviously really sad [to presume to Eungella gastric-brooding frog as extinct]\u00a0but it means you probably then start investing your resources in the next most threatened things,\" he said.\u00a0", "
Life finds a way\u00a0
", "Now, scientists from across the world have banded together in an extraordinary effort to undo the extinction of the exceptionally unusual frog.\u00a0", "Mike Archer, professor of Biological Science at the University of New South Wales, put together a team of scientists from as far away as Mongolia to work on cloning a southern gastric-brooding frog from a frozen sample.\u00a0", "\"It was an individual that was in a breeding colony in the University of Adelaide about 40 years ago,\" Professor Archer said.\u00a0", "", "
Scientists are using a frozen sample of what was one of the last southern gastric-brooding frogs in captivity.\u00a0(Supplied: Mike Tyler)
", "In 2013, the team had success in a somatic cell nuclear transfer.\u00a0", "\"This is where you take the nucleus from the cell of your extinct species\u00a0and inject that into an enucleated cell of a related living species, in an egg,\" Mr Archer said.\u00a0", "After hundreds of trials, they successfully transferred a cell, and started to divide it into a ball of cells.\u00a0", "While they could confirm it was the DNA of the extinct frog that was building and replicating cells, the process stopped as quickly as it started.\u00a0", "To the scientists' disappointment, the cells did not go on to develop a more complex embryo, which would have gone on to become a tadpole.\u00a0", "Trials doing the elaborate cell transfer on other, living frogs also proved unsuccessful, meaning the technique rather than the frog's DNA was at fault.\u00a0", "
'Beyond the edge of known science'
", "The team is now experimenting with these procedures and looking for alternative approaches.\u00a0", "But there is no way to know when they could make a breakthrough, and Professor Archer knows other challenges lie ahead.\u00a0", "\"When you're at beyond the age of the known science, there's no signpost\u00a0to tell you how much further you have to go to succeed,\" Mr Archer said.\u00a0", "", "
Despite the gastric-brooding frog being frozen in a conventional freezer for around\u00a040 years, scientists were able to get a suitable frozen tissue samples to start the somatic cell nuclear transfer.\u00a0(Supplied: Bob Beale)
", "\"In life the gastric-brooding frogs, the females swallow the fertilised eggs, but we don't have any adult females anymore to do that.\"", "While the experiments are being undertaken on the southern species of gastric-brooding frog, the team do have a frozen northern frog sample.\u00a0", "The technology isn't reserved solely for frogs, either, with Professor\u00a0Archer already worked on a project that has sequenced the whole genome for the Tasmanian Tiger [Thylacine].", "\"If we are responsible for having seen species declined to the point of extinction, I really think we have a moral responsibility to step in,\" Mr Archer said.\u00a0", "\"If the technology is there, or even if we need to build the technology.\"", "\"It's about trying to demonstrate that we can fix what we've broken.\"\u00a0"]
